alert.note: Alert for Coastal Hancock (Maine) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Watch issued December 09 at 11:40AM EST until December 11 at 4:00PM EST by NWS Caribou
info.description: ...Heavy Rain and Snowmelt Flooding Sunday night into Monday night... A strong low pressure system will bring heavy rainfall to northern and eastern Maine. Rainfall of 1 to 3 inches with some locally higher amounts is expected. The rainfall will combine with snowmelt and a partially frozen ground to cause small stream, creek and river flooding. ...FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM LATE SUNDAY NIGHT THROUGH TUESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues to be possible. * WHERE...Portions of Central Highlands, Coastal DownEast, Far Eastern, Interior DownEast, and Penobscot Valley Maine, including the following areas, in Central Highlands Maine, Northern Penobscot. In Coastal DownEast Maine, Coastal Hancock and Coastal Washington. In Far Eastern Maine, Northern Washington and Southeast Aroostook. In Interior DownEast Maine, Central Washington and Interior Hancock. In Penobscot Valley Maine, Central Penobscot and Southern Penobscot. * WHEN...From late Sunday night through Tuesday morning. * IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. The Piscataquis River may reach minor flood stage with a rapid response to snowmelt plus rainfall in complex terrain. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rainfall and warm temperatures will melt most, if not all, existing snowpack. The heavy rainfall, snowmelt, and high rainfall rates over a partially frozen ground will create a scenario promoting small stream, creek and river flooding. - For flood safety tips visit, http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: You should monitor later forecasts and be alert for possible Flood Warnings. Those living in areas prone to flooding should be prepared to take action should flooding develop.
